metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin (Miyun site-eddy covariance system) (2008-2010)
metadata.description:
The data set contains vortex related flux observation data on January 1, 2008, solstice, December 29, 2010.The site is located in xinchengzi town, miyun county, Beijing, with orchards (plums and apple trees), corn/bare land, and towns.The latitude and longitude of the observation point is 117.3233E, 40.6308N, and the altitude is 350m.
The acquisition frequency of the eddy correlativity instrument is 10Hz, the frame height is 26.66m, the ultrasonic direction is due to the north, and the distance between the ultrasonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O analyzer is 25cm.The published data is the 30-minute data obtained by the post-processing of the original collected 10Hz data with Edire software. The main steps of the processing include: outfield value elimination, delay time correction, coordinate rotation (plane fitting), frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction and density (WPL) correction.Quality assessment for each intercompared to at the same time, mainly is the atmospheric stability (Δ st) and turbulent characteristics of similarity (ITC) test.The 30min pass value output by Edire software was also screened :(1) the data when the instrument was wrong was removed;(2) data of 1h before and after precipitation were excluded;(3) the missing rate of 10Hz original data is more than 3% every 30min;(4) the observed data of weak turbulence at night were excluded (u* less than 0.1m/s).The average period of observation data was 30 minutes, 48 data a day, and the missing data was marked as -6999.
The observation data released by vortex correlator include:Date/Time for the Date/Time, wind Wdir (°), Wnd horizontal wind speed (m/s), standard deviation Std_Uy lateral wind speed (m/s), ultrasonic virtual temperature Tv (℃), the water vapor density H2O (g/m3), carbon dioxide concentration CO2 (mg/m3), friction velocity Ustar) (m/s), the length of cloth hoff, sensible heat flux Hs (W/m2), latent heat flux LE (W/m2), carbon dioxide flux Fc (mg/(m2s)), the quality of the sensible heat flux identifier QA_Hs, the quality of the latent heat flux identifier QA_LE,Carbon dioxide flux mass identification QA_Fc.The quality of the sensible heat and latent heat, carbon dioxide flux identification is divided into nine grades (quality logo 1: (0 < Δ st < 15, 0 < ITC < 30);2: (16 < < 30, 0 < ITC Δ st < 30);3: (0 < Δ st < 30, 31 < ITC < 75);4: (31 < < 75, 0 < ITC Δ st < 30);5: (0 < Δ st < 75, 31 < ITC < 100);6 (76 < < 100, ITC Δ st < 100);7: (Δ st < 250, ITC < 250);8: (Δ st < 1000, ITC < 1000);The rest are 9).The meaning of data time, such as 0:30 represents the average between 0:00 and 0:30;The data is stored in *.xls format.
Please refer to Jia et al.(2012) for information of observation test or site, and Liu et al.(2013) for data processing.

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

background: Sensible and latent heat fluxes are important indicators reflecting the intensity of heat and water vapor exchange between the land and atmosphere, influencing the energy balance between them, providing material, dynamic, and thermal sources for weather systems of different scales, and affecting the water cycle process between the land and atmosphere. Currently, there are many traditional methods for observing surface fluxes, such as the Eddy-Covariance system (EC), Bowen ratio-energy balance system, and aerodynamic methods. Among these, the Eddy-Covariance system is internationally recognized as the most reliable method for observing surface fluxes; however, its observation scale is relatively small, with spatial representativeness of only tens to hundreds of meters. The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS), in contrast to traditional Eddy-Covariance systems, can obtain average sensible heat fluxes at a regional scale (from hundreds of meters to several kilometers). Since the observation scale of LAS aligns well with satellite pixel scales and the grid scales of numerical weather prediction and climate models, the observations from LAS can serve as ground truth for the pixel/grid scale of remote sensing estimation models, numerical weather prediction models, and climate models, thereby optimizing and validating these models. The observation principle of LAS is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST), which, combined with the atmospheric refractive index structure parameter C2n and related meteorological data, utilizes the stability universal function fT related to the temperature structure parameter C2T to obtain the regional average sensible heat flux at the surface.
research objective: Using the LAS-related data from Guantao Station (January to December 2009) and Arou Station (January to June and October to November), the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in LAS observations was analyzed, and a quantitative assessment method for the applicability of MOST was explored.
challenges: Due to the influence of underlying surface cover types, flatness, water-heat conditions, and weather conditions, it is difficult to achieve the ideal assumption of uniformity in practice. Currently, domestic research on atmospheric similarity theory mainly focuses on the similarity relationships of wind, temperature profiles, and turbulence variance. However, there is relatively little research on the similarity between temperature structure parameters and turbulence characteristics in the context of scintillation methods.
methods: Before analyzing the applicability of the MOST theory to LAS data, preliminary processing of EC and LAS data is conducted. LAS, EC, and AWS data from the Guantao Station (January to December 2009) and the Aru Station (January to June and October to November) are selected.
dataset:
Guantao Station (36°30′54″N, 115°07′39″E) is located in Hezhai Village, Guantao County, Hebei Province. Its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of farmland, including winter wheat, corn, and cotton, with winter wheat and corn being rotated. The growth period for winter wheat is from October to June of the following year, while corn grows from June to October, and cotton grows from May to October. This area represents a typical farmland underlying surface of the North China Plain. In the LAS source area, the area of winter wheat (corn) accounts for about 45%, while cotton accounts for about 47%. 

Arou Station (38°02′40″N, 100°27′53″E) is located in the valley area upstream of the Heihe River, where its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of typical alpine grassland, which is relatively flat. The vegetation in the source area can reach a height of 0.2 to 0.3 meters during the growing season.
findings: (1) Under unstable conditions, large-scale vortex motion, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales can significantly affect the applicability of the MOST theory; (2) Two new methods for assessing the applicability of the MOST theory have been established, namely factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, and it has been verified that these two assessment methods are reasonable and reliable.

background: For surface flux measurements, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has become more and more popular in recent years. Compared with traditional observation techniques, it can measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km). At present, LAS observation is not common in China.
research objective: The daily and monthly variation of HLAS is analyzed. And the observation differences between eddy covariance system and LAS, need to be studied further combined with footprint model and energy unbalance of eddy covariance system observation.
challenges: There is much less agreement on the form which universal stability function fT should take. Further more, since the iteration process of HLAS can not be convergence when low wind speed and very stable conditions appearing at night, Wm \ - 5 is specified.
findings: Sensible heat flux (H) calculation with the LAS data of above measurements shows that the beam height of LAS and wind speed are sensitive factors for sensible heat flux measurement (HLAS), zero-plane displacement height is crucial unless the beam height is much larger than it, and Bowen ratio needs to be determined accurately over wet surface, while air temperature, air pressure and aerodynamic roughness length are not sensitive for HLAS. According to the observations mentioned above, LAS can measure surface fluxes both over homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Is the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory applicable for analyzing data collected by large aperture scintillometers under various surface conditions?

Concept Completion.Question: What challenges are faced when applying data collection methods to measure surface fluxes in different environmental contexts?

Example.Question: Can you illustrate an example of how the eddy covariance system is utilized for surface flux measurements in agricultural settings?
Example.Answer: The eddy covariance system was used to measure surface fluxes at a site located in Miyun, Beijing, over an orchard with plum and apple trees, corn/bare soil, and urban areas. The system collected data at a frequency of 10Hz, which was processed using Edire software to produce 30-minute averaged data. This method includes steps like outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, sonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when applying the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in large aperture scintillometer (LAS) observations, and how was it addressed?
Example.Answer: One challenge in applying MOST theory to LAS observations is that actual conditions often do not meet the ideal homogeneous assumption due to varied surface types and weather conditions. To address this, two new methods for judging the applicability of MOST were established: factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods. These methods were found to be reasonable and reliable.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is calculated over heterogeneous surfaces using experimental data?
Example.Answer: In the Xiaotangshan Experiment conducted in Beijing, z0m was calculated over different surfaces by first calculating individual z0m values for each surface component using roughness elements' characteristics such as vegetation height and leaf area index. Then, an aggregated z0m over the entire experimental field was determined using a footprint weighting method, highlighting the directional dependency of z0m due to the spatial distribution and size of roughness elements.

Definition.Question: What is the definition of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) in the context of surface flux estimations?
Definition.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. It is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. It describes the roughness characteristics of a surface, influenced by the structure and spacing of roughness elements like plants and other obstacles on the land surface.

Definition.Question: How is the eddy covariance system defined as a method for surface flux measurements?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance system is defined as an internationally recognized and reliable method for surface flux measurements, particularly for small spatial scales. It measures the exchange of gases, heat, and momentum between the surface and the atmosphere by capturing the turbulence data over time, typically with equipment like ultrasonic anemometers and gas analyzers.

Definition.Question: How is the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) determined in the context of large aperture scintillometer (LAS) observations?
Definition.Answer: The applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in LAS observations is determined by analyzing the stability of atmospheric conditions and the development of turbulence. Specifically, it considers factors like large-scale eddy movement and temperature scales. Two new methods for assessing MOST applicability are the factor analysis method and the temperature structure parameter method, which have been validated as reasonable and reliable.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using eddy-covariance systems compare to those employing large aperture scintillometers in terms of spatial representativeness and scale of observation?
Comparison.Answer: Eddy-covariance systems are internationally recognized as reliable methods for surface flux observations, but they have a smaller spatial representativeness, typically only covering tens to hundreds of meters. In contrast, large aperture scintillometers can achieve regional scale observations, covering several hundred meters to kilometers, which aligns better with satellite pixel scales and grid scales of numerical weather prediction and climate models.

Interpretation.Question: What implications does the directional dependency of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) have for modeling surface fluxes in areas with heterogeneous land surfaces?
Interpretation.Answer: The directional dependency of z0m, as influenced by the heterogeneity of roughness elements, highlights the need for models to account for the spatial distribution and size of these elements along different wind directions. Understanding this dependency can improve the parameterization of z0m in remote sensing and land surface models, leading to more accurate flux estimations over diverse terrains.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory essential in the calculation of sensible heat fluxes for large aperture scintillometer observations, and what challenges arise from its application?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory is essential in calculating sensible heat fluxes because it accounts for atmospheric refractive index structure parameters and stability functions. However, challenges arise due to the difficulty in maintaining the ideal homogeneous surface assumption, especially under varying terrain and atmospheric conditions, affecting the theory's applicability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the variability in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) measurements across different land surfaces, and how does this impact surface flux estimation models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Variability in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is caused by differences in surface roughness elements such as vegetation height and spatial distribution. This variability impacts surface flux estimation models by requiring parameterizations that account for these differences to improve model accuracy over heterogeneous surfaces.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the likely outcomes of utilizing high-frequency data collection methods, such as 10Hz sampling, for capturing surface flux variations in different land cover types?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing high-frequency data collection, like 10Hz sampling, allows for capturing fine-scale variations in surface fluxes over different land cover types, providing detailed insights into the interactions between vegetation and atmospheric dynamics. This can lead to more accurate assessments of heat and moisture exchange processes, as well as enhanced understanding of energy balance over diverse landscapes such as orchards, urban areas, and agricultural fields.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to examine the applicability of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory in large aperture scintillometer observations over different terrains?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to examine the applicability of Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory in large aperture scintillometer observations to ensure the reliability of sensible heat flux measurements, considering the influence of terrain characteristics such as surface roughness, vegetation cover, and atmospheric conditions that can affect the theory's assumptions and applicability.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind analyzing the aerodynamic roughness length variations using data from the Xiaotangshan Experiment?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals behind analyzing the aerodynamic roughness length variations using data from the Xiaotangshan Experiment include calculating roughness lengths over different surfaces, understanding the directional characteristics of roughness over heterogeneous landscapes, and developing parameterizations that relate roughness length to land surface properties for improved model applications.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key procedural steps involved in preprocessing eddy covariance data to ensure accuracy and reliability in surface flux measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The key procedural steps include despiking to remove outliers, time delay correction, coordinate rotation using the planar fit method, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction (WPL correction). Additionally, data quality is evaluated based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity tests. Data is also filtered by removing erroneous data, data influenced by precipitation, and data with more than 3% missing in a 30-minute interval, as well as weak turbulence data during nighttime.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) calculated over different land surfaces, and what are the challenges associated with its estimation using remote sensing models?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is calculated using wind profile measurements based on Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory. It involves calculating individual z0m over each surface component with parameters like vegetation height and leaf area index, and then aggregating these using the footprint weighting method. The challenges include the large variation range of z0m over different surfaces and the difficulty in obtaining z0m for local or regional scales using station observations alone.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are necessary to evaluate the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in analyzing large aperture scintillometer (LAS) data for surface flux measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps include preprocessing of eddy covariance (EC) and LAS data, selecting relevant datasets from specific observation periods, and analyzing the data to assess the MOST theory's applicability. New quantitative methods, such as factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, are used to determine the suitability of MOST theory, considering factors like large-scale eddy movements, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales under unstable conditions.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques are essential for ensuring the accuracy and quality of surface flux measurements from eddy covariance systems?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing techniques essential for ensuring accuracy and quality include wild point value exclusion, time delay correction, coordinate rotation using the planar fit method, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Additionally, quality evaluation of flux values is performed based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics.

Enablement.Question: How do large aperture scintillometers contribute to the understanding of surface fluxes compared to traditional eddy covariance systems?
Enablement.Answer: Large aperture scintillometers (LAS) enable measurement of surface fluxes on a regional scale (hundreds of meters to kilometers), which better matches satellite pixel scales and numerical weather prediction grid scales. This allows LAS observations to serve as relative ground truth for remote sensing estimation models, numerical weather prediction models, and climate models, providing a means to optimize and validate these models.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in applying the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory for large scale flux measurements in heterogeneous landscapes?
Expectation.Answer: The applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory can be affected by factors such as large scale eddy movements, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales under unstable conditions, which are common in heterogeneous landscapes.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges associated with using eddy-covariance systems for surface flux measurements, especially in terms of data collection and quality assurance?
Judgmental.Answer: One of the primary challenges with eddy-covariance systems is their limited spatial representativeness, as their observational scale is relatively small, typically only tens to hundreds of meters. Additionally, ensuring data quality involves complex processing steps such as despiking, time delay correction, and coordinate rotation, which must be performed rigorously to maintain reliability. Challenges also arise from environmental conditions like precipitation, which necessitate data filtering, and the need for quality assessment of flux values based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity.

Judgmental.Question: How do large aperture scintillometers (LAS) compare to eddy-covariance systems in terms of their suitability for regional-scale surface flux measurements?
Judgmental.Answer: Large aperture scintillometers are advantageous over eddy-covariance systems when it comes to measuring surface fluxes on a regional scale, as they can cover distances from a few hundred meters to several kilometers. LAS is particularly suitable for matching satellite pixel scales and the grid scales of numerical weather prediction and climate models, providing a more representative ground truth for these models. However, the suitability of LAS for certain conditions, such as very stable atmospheric conditions at night, can be limited, which requires careful consideration of stability functions and beam height in data interpretation.

Judgmental.Question: What datasets or data collection methods could be utilized to improve the parameterization of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) in remote sensing models or land surface models?
Judgmental.Answer: To enhance the parameterization of aerodynamic roughness length in models, datasets from experiments like the Xiaotangshan Experiment could be utilized. These datasets include measurements of aerodynamic roughness length over various surfaces, along with characteristics of roughness elements such as vegetation height and leaf area index. Using footprint models to analyze directional dependence and aggregating z0m values over heterogeneous surfaces can provide heuristic parameterizations that are more applicable for remote sensing and land surface models. Additionally, datasets that capture the temporal and spatial variability of z0m across different land covers and conditions would be valuable for improving model accuracy.

Assertion.Answer: The quality of eddy covariance data is evaluated using criteria such as atmospheric stability (Δst) and turbulent similarity characteristics (ITC). The data processing involves steps like outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density correction (WPL). Quality assessments are performed, classifying flux quality into nine levels.

LAS data can serve as ground truth values for optimizing and validating these models, thus enhancing their accuracy.

This parameterization is crucial for surface flux estimations using remote sensing algorithms and land surface models, as z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.

Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for analyzing aerodynamic roughness length variations include those from experimental setups like the Xiaotangshan Experiment, which collected data over several years and used analytical footprint models to analyze z0m over heterogeneous surfaces. This approach involves relating z0m to roughness element characteristics such as vegetation height and leaf area index.
